App Title: The Curious Tale of the Stolen Pets
App description:
*Now playable with Hand Tracking!*

Help your grandfather solve the mystery of the stolen pets by exploring wonderful miniature worlds crafted from the ground up for VR. Every world is unique, full of interactions and colorful life.

A HEART-WARMING TALE
Guided by the voice of your grandfather, travel back to the imaginative adventures of your childhood and the worlds you created together. Revisit a joyful past and the troubled relationship with your sister. 

PEACEFUL PUZZLING
Proceed through the game by solving light puzzles using your hands; Grip, push, drop and spin the numerous interactive elements. Every world is full of vibrant life. 

WORLDS OF HIDDEN WONDER
Peek behind a glowing volcano in the prehistoric setting or lean in to investigate your old summer cottage. Explore incredibly detailed and handcrafted worlds while enjoying gameplay tailor-made for VR.

NukemarineFeb 4 at 5:08 AM
Beautiful game, but really short

I love 3rd person games. Even better are miniature 3rd person games like BlazeRush, Witchblood, Moss, etc. The Curious Tale fills that enjoyment though it's less third person and more model puzzle solving. If you ever seen the VR short-story of The Rose or The Matchstick Girl, TCToSP has those visuals including The Matchstick Girl's stop-motion like framerate for characters moving around. On top of that, there's a nice narration by the grandfather figure throughout the games five puzzle levels and intermissions.

Gameplay is pretty straight forward. You have five miniature asteroid worlds (shades of The Little Prince) you can control through rotation and elevation with thumbsticks or grabbing (use the thumbsticks). It may even be fun if you have the room to walk around the model instead of moving it. You can grab small items or click on them for interaction to complete the simple puzzles and find hidden items if you consider the glowing stars pointing to the locations as hidden.

That said, this is a very short game. If you buy it, expect to beat it in under an hour. The puzzles are not that mind-bending and you might find it harder to find the various coins than the hidden pets (not sure if stolen ever came into play). Given its simplicity and warm hearted story you might just want to show this off to other people. You're given 3 save spots so that's easy enough.

Four stars just for the short play length. With more levels, this could be a five star game at the given price. I wouldn't mind being able to look at the levels at human scale in first person as well (perhaps clicking on the human characters or pets for their POV).

They are designed outstandingly, with a level of details that make them feel like living places.
